Most of the points made in my review still apply, but I will no longer be playing this game due to optimization issues.So im almost at the 500 hour mark... time for a real steam review.Homebrew Vehicle Sandbox is exactly what it says on the tin. There is one large map populated with several islands that you can roam around in, and there is also a garage where you can create literally any kind of vehicle you can imagine. Their is no questline or story (as of yet), just exploring the map with wacky vehicles and your buddies on the many multiplayer servers available.+The only limit to what you can build is yourself. Build planes, jets, boats, hot air balloons, tanks, jet-powered flying shlongs. You name it, it can be built.+Easy building interface. The building mechanics are a cross between voxel-based and components-based, with 'pipes' acting as frame pieces which specialized components can be attached to.+Incredibly realistic physics engine. Aerodynamics plays a massive part in air vehicles, and at least a basic understanding of real-life physics is needed to make more complicated vehicles.+Playerbase is incredibly nice and helpful. The devs are very communicative and can often be found playing on their own servers, where you can then bombard them with questions and reccomendations for the game.+Online multiplayer. Once you're done exploring the map, you can join an online "party" and blast people out of the air with hellfire missiles >:D=Large learning curve due to the realistic physics. You cant just slap a few rockets on a car and fly rings around towers, a lot of tweaking and testing is required to perfect your vehicles.=Controller support is largely incomplete, limiting controller use to the simpler vehicles.-Button mapping is just god-awful. Homebrew implements a button-mapping system that allows you to assign keys to basic functions, and then assign those functions to components. To be honest it would be a lot easier if I could just assign keys to components, rather than this in-between system.-Still very buggy. None of them gamebreaking, but it can be quite annoying when a vehicle ive been working on for an hour gets corrupted and no longer usable.-Graphics arent that great (I honestly dont give a fart about graphics, but there are people out there who think otherwise).

								Update: 01/15/15--I highly recommend downloading the demo (which I had no clue was available at the time of purchase) from the game's website (http://www.homebrewgame.com). Personal experience will tell you far better than any review whether or not you'll find this game worth the money. --My "no" recommendation is MUCH more qualified than earlier. The game has been streamlined a bit, optimized a lot, and shows no signs of ceasing improvement.In addition, the developers added a link in-game to community YouTube tutorials and improved its in-game manual. The physics are still cardboard-balloonish, but I feel like they will improve with time.In addition, as you can see below, the developers definitely care about this game and LISTEN to criticism rather than trying to squash it, which makes them ok in my book.I still honestly think it's too rough to justify the price, but I sincerely think that could change if development continues at this pace.----------Previous review----My "No" Recommendation is qualified; please read the full review for an explaination.If you're anything like me, you played Banjo Kazooie: Nuts & Bolts and fell in love with the vehicle-building system.Ever since I played that game, I've been looking for a game that was essentially -just- the "screwing around with vehicles" aspect of BK:N&B. When I saw this on the store page, I thought I'd found it.So far, I was wrong. It definitely has promise; don't misunderstand me. Conceptually, it really is a neat vehicle-building sandbox. But it's in rough, ROUGH alpha shape. The physics are currently of the "cardboard balloons" variety, the camera is weird and unintuitive, and the game still isn't great at explaining how to use all its features. It's not egregiously bad and it's not unplayable, but it feels like it's a very long way from the finish line.Now, then: If I don't think it's -that- bad, why am I not recommending it? Well, because of the price. So many Early Access games do this; they take an early build and charge way too much for it. If this game was $4.99 in its current state, I'd recommend it pretty solidly, because there's enough here to be mildly entertaining for now and enough promise to keep an eye on the game. As it stands, $17.99 (or $15-ish at the moment) is just too much cash to drop on something this rough.If the dev keeps working on it, this game CAN be the game I've dreamed of, and when it's closer to that, I'll heartily recommend it. Early Access Review
								Due to life being life, I haven't had as much time to play this title as  I'd like to.  But I've played enough to realize that this game is downright awesome.  Sadly, for some reason, it has remained criminally underrated here on Steam.  It deserves far more attention and DEFINITELY does not deserve the negative ratings it has gotten recently.  Most of the negative reviews I've read stem from two general complaints, both of which are stupid, as I shall now explain...Stupid Complaint # 1 - "This game is tooo Harrd!  How doo I vehicle more?"Explanation: This is a physics and engineering sandbox game,  consisting essentially of two elements: a set of tools with which players can create machines; and an environment in which they can observe and interact with those machines.  The more robust and detailed these two elements are, the more complex the software will be.  This is inevitable.  If you want the power and freedom to create fantastic, interesting machines, you MUST be willing to learn how to use the advanced tools required to do so.  There are plenty of avenues to learn how to play this game.  If you don't want to learn anything new - fine.  Go play Doom or Flappy Bird or whatever.  But don't blame this game for your laziness.Stupid Complaint # 2: "This game has bugs / incomplete features.  It's like they're charging us for EARLY ACCESS to their unfinished game!  WTF?!"Explanation:  Firstly, learn to read.  Second, use your newfound reading skill to acquire knowledge about products BEFORE you spend money on them.  This strategy will reduce the likelihood that you will purchase something you do not actually want, such as an early access copy of a game that is still under development.  If you review an early access game, you have to review it AS SUCH.  As of the writing of this review, there have been 71 announcements from the developers.  Seventy-fricking-one!  A little research will quickly show that the game is under active development and there is a great relationship between the devs and the community. This is pretty much all that can be asked of an early access title (and it's a hell of a lot more than you'll get from most games currently listed as early access).  If you don't like early access, don't buy it until it's finished.  But don't criticize the game for not being complete when it isn't claiming to be so. Ignoring the negative reviews based on the two stupid reasons I just debunked, you'll see that this game has gotten a lot of positive feedback.  And it clearly deserves it.  There are very quality few games in this genre.  I have scoured every corner of Steam, and I can name every one I found on one hand.  Kerbal Space Program, Space Engineers, From the Depths, and Homebrew Vehicle Sandbox - if you know of a single other title worthy of being on that list, I'd love to hear it.  In the meantime, if you like any one of those games, I suggest buying them all.  Between the four of them, you should have enough to keep you occupied for at least a decade or two.

Early Access Review
								::DISCLAIMER:: This review does not represent some of the newer features/fixes that have been introduced as of Jan 15, 2017. I understand that new parts have been added and a procedural wing genereator has been added as well but I haven't extensively looked at these updates. There is still no mirror/symmtrey mode from what I can tell. That, more than anything is discouraging me from playing. I will update this review accordingly next time I look at the game. ::DISCLAIMER OVER::It pains me to write a negative review for this game but at this point, i'm left with no choice. To sum up my experience with this game (more specifically the building component) I find myself getting frustrated and annoyed everytime I try to do something.BuilderI only really enjoy building planes, but that's not the games fault, i'm just not interested in building cars. One of my biggest gripes is that there's no mirror mode. You want to build a twin engined plane? You'll have to build the engine twice. You want to put windows on it? You'll have to build them twice. You want a gear retraction mechanism? You'll have to bui..you get the point. It makes EVERYTHING more tedious and difficult than it should be. I've spent hours trying to build and "skin" an aircraft only to find that the skin plate on one side was like, one notch off. IF THERE WAS A MIRROR MODE, I wouldn't have even had that problem in the first place, or at least, it would have been easier to fix. But instead it took me another 2 hours just to nail down what exactly was wrong and pretty much re-adjust every single other skin plate in order to fix it. I don't know why this feature has not been made a priority, it seems like it's pretty standard with most other creative building games. Aviation PartsAnother issue I have (granted it's not a huge issue) is the lack of plane parts. I don't mean the number of plane parts, I mean the types. You're basically limited to general aviation 4 seater aircraft or SUPER-SONIC FIGHTER JETS!! There's no inbetween. If you want to build a mid-sized aircraft, you're pretty much stuck either slapping a bunch of cessna wings on it or putting up with a weird looking wing that's the same size as your plane and intended for speeds above mach 1. I would like to see a procedural wing generator but I understand that's probably not the easiest thing to do so I would be happy to even see wings analagous to something like a Beechcraft 1900. BugsIt's unfortunetly got a lot of bugs. It seems like everytime there's a new update, there's a new bug I have to deal with. THIS time the clickspots are offset from the actual menu so your mouse has to be below the button to actually click it. It the button is near the bottom of the screen then you're pretty much screwed. It's not present in fullscreen it seems but that just means you're committed to using full screen mode. That and there's a meriad of little things that are annoying such as not being able to hook up strobe lights to batteries making them completely useless. EARLY ACCESSThis game has been in alpha for almost two years. Really? It's another example of an early access game that just never leaves this state, or if it does, it's at the expense of the player base(see SpaceBase DF9). If I had to make a guess, it will never leave alpha (PROVE ME WRONG COPY-BUG-PASTE!), that just seems to be the trend of early access games these days. Updates are few and far between, offering (usually) little in gameplay content. An exception to this is the "recent" multiplayer update, but even that was riddled with bugs and we had to wait a few more days for it to be in a USABLE state. Even today the multiplayer button still says [EXPERIMENTAL] on it..The Good NewsIt's not all bad. If you have the paitence to learn how to build and to do the actual building, it's actually pretty enjoyable. There's nothing more rewarding than building something that works just the way you want it to. Making small adjustments and tweaks to fine tune your "creation" is surprisingly fun. The physics has been improved since HB13 and while it's certainly a long ways from being considered "realistic", it feels good for what it is and most importantly, it's fun. It's no X-Plane 10, but the aerodynamics are decent too. SummaryThis game is very close to being worth 20$, but it's not there yet for various reasons. The lack of updates is the biggest killer for me. I hate waiting a month for a feature that is either buggy or that i'll likely never use. Don't get me wrong, for the most part I enjoy this game or else I wouldn't have played it for 93+ hours and I WANT it to succeed! I think it has a lot of potential but I can't recommend a game on potential alone. 15$ is a more reasonable price for this in it's current state, also taking into consideration it's been almost two years since it was initially released on steam. I'll give this a thumbs up when meaningful updates become more frequent, and I can actually play it for more than 10 minutes without my blood pressure going through the roof.

								So Homebrew.  Lets see, where to start?  Is the game good?  Yes!  Am I good with reveiws?  Absolutely not.  But how else are you gonna know it is good unless people tell you it is.  Whether or not they're good at telling you it is good.  But enough of that, on to the actual reveiw I guess.So yeah.  Homebrew...  Obviously this isn't a game about brewing moonshine in your back yard over a can of beer.  Which is kinda pointless, since you're drinking other alchohal that you payed for while making alchohal that you sell to pay for buying other alchohol, so WTF.  Anyway, we're not doing any of that in Homebrew.  In Homebrew Vehicle Sandbox, you're making your own vehicles and enjoying created vehicles within a sandbox environment.  So sorry all you moonshiners, but this is not a game about making moonshine.  Instead, Homebrew is about embracing creativity, in whatever form that may come in, and making vehicles with it.  Be it cars, trucks, planes, boats, airships, helicopters, Gundams, trains, hoverbikes, rockets, etc.  You name it and, with enough creativity and the right know-how, you can make it.  You can even sorta "code" videogames inside Homebrew!Homebrew does this by offering an expansive vehicle builder allowing you to combine all kinds of parts to make whatever you want.  Including a unique take on logic systems that most other vehicle building games simply don't offer.  Certainly not Space Engineers or Scrap Mechanic.Homebrew really has something in it for everyone.  If you like a certain car a lot, you can replicate it in Homebrew.  If you've got some crazy idea for a plane, you can build it in Homebrew and enjoy all that wackiness from the safety of your living room.  If you're an artist, Homebrew certainly isn't any kind of sculpting or painting software.  However, you can still make brilliant artwork by using it. Even for those fancy coding ninjas out there, I've personally made several videogames within Homebrew, including Pong and Flappy Bird, to name two popular examples.  While I'll admit there isn't currently a coding language that you use to create these games, it is in the works and will definitely be featured later on.  For the time being, it is a little clunky to code games within Homebrew, but I think I've proven it possible.Not to speak lightly of it by making it my last point, but Homebrew also has amazing developers and community.  If you're having trouble with anything related to the game, or even things not related to the game, shoot the community a question and you'll get a friendly answer fairly soon.  And if not, the devs themselves will usually come help you out!  How awesome is that?Personally, I love Homebrew.  It is no doubt my favorite game.  Granted, Homebrew has more than its fair share of bugs (at the time of writing), but those are being steadilly ironed out, and Homebrew is steadilly growing as well.  It's hard to say where Homebrew will be in 2 years.  But I can definitely say the devs are on the right track and are well on the way to making a game that pretty much everyone can enjoy.- - - - - Now I suppose I should add a few downsides (cons) as well, shouldn't I?  Well, I'm really having a lot of trouble thinking up some, but I'll give it a go.First major con:  The game has more than it's fair share of bugs.  I know I already said that pretty much word for word before, but it is worth mentioning.  Granted, none of them are really game-breaking, but they are noticeable.  There are usualy workarounds that us players can utilize, And the devs are constantly at work fixing up one bug or another.  But certain bugs have remained in the game for quite some time, and are fairly easy to spot within the first 50 hours of playing the game.Second major con:  Updates can be rather slow.  At times we've been over 2 months between updates.  While Homebrew devs are not the slowest, it can feel like it at times if you're  really  invested in the game.  Granted, they're always hard at work on cool new features, often times these are even features suggested by the community.  But my point still rings ever true.  The updates can be rather slow.

								Update Dev 2015: The v14 patch is here! This is a big one. The devs basically remade the game in Unity 5. Some of the systems are entirely re-done and it is overall a big improvement. I'll highlight a few great points below, but this isn't an exhaustive list of all the great changes / addition. + much more flexible building tools (like being able to adjust pipes _after_ welding them to your vehicle, etc). + you can save vehicles / sub-assemblies and spawn / weld them in other projects :)+ flexible plating / skin system: It's only the start right now but there are already some easy to use parts for making body panels that far surpass the rigid old dog plates from v13. + support for the most wanted thing in this game: servos! Actuators, servo motors, whatever you want to call them. Finally it is very easy to make all manner of things from turrets and landing gear, to swept wings and shuttle bay doors!+ Great kismet / wiring system. Most of the parts input and/or output (as required) float numbers (generally normalized between -1 and 1) for their functions. You can link inputs and outputs as you want, and there are a variety of modifier parts for combining / shifting / gating / etc the values as you go along. This makes it possible to do things like have a gyrosensor used to adjust the flaps on your plane to keep it level, while still combining it with the input from the user's seat. + better physics. I suppose that matters. Center of mass / lift calculated in much better fashion now. It means if you make something that looks like it should fly, it probably will ^___^+ waves on da ocean ----------------------------------------------Update Jan 2015: The devs removed the orbs a few patches ago, and now it is a proper sandbox mode (once you complete the initial tutorial). Now you can unleash your creative potential almost immediately!  It is much better this way. As the game stands now there are lots of things to play with in terms of vehicle parts, and the devs have a lot of cool things in the pipeline too. It's damn fun. Looking forward to future updates :)Pre-update review: This game would be great if you didn't have to go about collecting annoying little orbs to unlock parts. For a game advertising extensive freedom that seems like an unnecessary and arbitrary restriction, especially for a pre-alpha or whatever it is.(recommended nonetheless)

Early Access Review
								Homebrew is a vehicle building game where its worst feature is the vehicle building.The graphics are okay, the sounds are... ehh, the prebuilt vehicles are *awesome*, the game world is huge and varied and the idea of building the stuff of your dreams is enticing enough to get you to build.And then you realize how sucky building is.For starters, the builder has physics on it, meaning every part that's not tied to the starting node will fall to the ground and tumble, making you adjust your camera, go around to the face you want to weld to your vehicle, click it, and then back to the vehicle to select the part to weld it to. It has no symmetry tools either, which will force you to do each thing twice for the other side of it. You can build custom pipes which is great in theory but then you realize you have to do it *again* for every single one you build. On top of that, parts are throughly premade and scaling is almost non existant, limited to a handful of *components* (not whole parts), and the few that include rescaling only allow for very limited options (you can make a rectangular  wing wider and longer, but not change its shape). You can't move stuff easily either, if you want to shift a set of parts sightly forward or backward you will have to disconnect the root part which will make EVERYTHING disconnect from each other and fall to the ground. The selection of parts is adequate, but with fixed dimensions and with the busywork of having to do symmetry manually the frustration will quickly set in.You do link parts manually, which is great, letting you make very complex inner workings, and stuff like gears and logical connectors also opens up a lot of ideas, but the game sorely lacks a lot of the basic building blocks that would make such a product enjoyable and accessible.3/10. The building really mares this game down to the point of unpleasantness, and though the more advanced options are really juicy looking, making anything in this game is an exercise in busywork, unpleasantness, and frustration. It has advanced very little since I tried it out a year or so ago, and it has no excuse for being this intensely clunky in a world where games like KSP and Empyrion exist.

The build system, while a bit tricky at first, is surprisingly flexible and for those of you who know gmod/source welds, it is refreshing in how rigid the various components are and how easy it is to lift the hood and really customize things from gear ratios to fuel tank sizes.At this point in development, there are few different components ranging from small gasoline engines to vectored thrust jet engines plus all the necessary connectors and logic components needed to make them do what you want with them.  A huge selling point here is that it is not a voxel based assembly system but rather more like legos where some of the legos come in different sizes and you can even bend them to meet the way you want them to.Once you bring your creations into the world they behave more or less how you would expect them to.  The physics need work but they are quite usable and in a lot of cases the developers took the time to really get things right rather than "cheating" like some other games do when it comes to the calculations behind the scenes.I personally like making 6 wheeled monster trucks to drive on a tight cliff track or to try to optimize my propeller on my small scout plane so that it rotates just shy of the speed of sound to keep it at optimum efficiency.Having followed the forums a little bit, I can see that there will be some upcoming updates to physics _and_ multiplayer which is quite exciting as I can't wait to race my solar powered cars around a huge oval track or try to find and shoot down other planes that encroach on my building area.  I won't use the word potential here because you really never know, but from what I see as an armchair designer/engineer, I can't wait.In conclusion:  Don't buy this if you don't want to be in an alpha test of a physics sandbox game that changes a lot for the better.  There are other games out there in a high level of development that will satisfy your desires better...but I can say I have never found a game like this that quite captures what it is I love to do-design and test vehicles in a varied and interesting environment.  Sprinkle in some multiplayer and some exciting new parts and you're looking at an excellent addition to the world of sandbox games.

								This one has grabbed me. It's not so much a game as a great kit for building things and trying them out in an expansive world. There is apparently a way to get around the orb gathering, but I'm not smart enough to figure out the hints on the forums and I got tired of standing around in the pyramid with a dumb look on my face. :) Anyway, if you like to build and test and basically fiddle around with mechanical systems, this game will keep you entertained for many hours.

								Overall, this game has alot of potential. Though at its current state, its not very detailed, in the way the mechanics work. If this is changed, then this could become a very fun tool to create new ideas in. Though at the moment, it feels more like a lego game. The Tutorial System Is very odd, and brief. Though if you can notice the little "?" Icon, there is more detail within it.Unfortunatly, when you finally finish creating something, it doesn't react the way you wanted it to, at all. Not because you failed at realizing the physics engine, but because it just isn't indepth as it needs to be.Physics, are, well to say the least, quite bad. For instance, If you were to make a basic plane, put four wings on it, and One Prop, and go full RPM, you will just go up in the air, and spin chaoticly in circles. Also there is no individual part physics involved. What I mean by this, is it doesn't seem like the prop (for instance) has its own weight, causing it to have no centrifugal force. Meaning there is no torque/pressure rotation in the given direction the prop is spinning from. - Aswell, as there is no way to view (while building your vehicle) where the weight lies within the vehicle parts and/or the completed vehicle. Which partially leads me to believe, that the weight is only cut into a hand full of segments on your final vehicle, instead of each part having its own weight. Now this may not seem big now, but it will make a significant difference of  a realisitic inventive experiences, down the road.- Due to the lack of realistic physics in this game, It makes your inventions feel... well, not so inventive. More like you've put some lego together(for an hr or two) and then started running around your room going... VROOOOOM!!! (not saying those weren't epic times, Just saying theres a time and place, and this isn't it.)The Keyboard layout, is boarder line. There are some odd keys like, P & M, that adjust your given throttle. Where R & F, would be significantly more suitable. (In opinion)HowEVER, if they can fix these things in updates, then it will become very rewarding. Though at the moment, when you are finaly done your craft/vehicle, the reward is very underwhelming.The way this Game sits, it should be roughly $9.99 CAD. Not $19,99. Future Updates, like Gear boxes, and/or Gear Systems, and 360 Degree hinges, Would add much more diversity. And of course, a better physics engine. :)

								A very fun vehicle building game with multiplayer mechanics and a powerful method of building which can be used to create anything you can think of. There are weapons and enemies to use them against but I don't want to spoil too much. You can obviously fight other players in your vehicles which is good fun, and since the devs have an armour plating system planned, thats gonna get really interesting.There is a varied map with roads, a swamp, large bodies of water, mountains and sand - so you can test your vehicle offline or with friends on a variety of surfaces/environments. The map hides lots of secrets, I haven't found them all and the community is still trying to figure out a few of the more enigmatic ones.People seem to be complaining that it is difficult to use, I have to say I wouldn't agree. I have nearly 42 hours on record at the time of writing this plus more before it was on steam. At hour 42+ I'm obviously a much better builder than I was at hour 0, but even at the start the system seemed intuitive and anything I didn't understand was cleared up by tutorials or help from the amazing community and dev support on the website.It's in alpha yes, and I am apprehensive about buying games in alpha sometimes but not with this one. There are bugs present as with all alphas, but there are no major gamebreakers. There has been regular updates and the devs are literally in constant communication with the players, and I know if I had a pressing issue with the game or needed help with mechanics of the game I'd be able to get it faster than pretty much any of the other games in my library, plus the community are always happy to help on the chat on the homebrew website or the group chat on steam.Overall a really good sandbox vehicle builder with massive potential that is going in the right direction. I'd reccomend it, just take half an hour to learn the building system at the start using tutorials (like you have to do with all other sandbox building games like KSP etc) and you'll have a blast.

Posted: October 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Homebrew is exactly as the title states, a vehicle sandbox game.  You create your own vehicles from scratch, frame, gas tank and all, and then take them into the medium size sandbox world surrounding the garage area you created the vehicle in.  You can design and craft anything from go-karts, golf carts, 4-wheelers, cars, dragsters, tanks, motorbikes, planes, helicopters, hovercrafts and more.There is a really extensive crafting system in this game, although I feel the tutorial and instruction set is lacking and the overall crafting system feels a bit cluttered, very unrefined, and generally clunky and lazily put-together.  There is multiplayer, which is a nice touch, but really doesn't fix any of the problems with the game itself.The vehicle controls are clunky and weird, making many of the vehicles hard to control, and the fact that the physics system in the game is very odd certainly doesn't do this problem any favors.  Also, not that a game like this should be about graphics, but the developers have obviously tried to bring something at least mildly modern-looking to the table, but last I saw, they have failed terribly.  The games graphics look like the industry standard as of 2006, and for a game that tries to have decent graphics, I consider this a failure.All-in-all, I do not recommend this game in its current state.  The graphics are outdated and poorly designed.  The physics is quirky, which compounds the issue that the controls are touchy, buggy and generally difficult to use, and the crafting system is really unrefined and includes part names like pipe_001, pipe_002, curvepipe_001 and so on.  The whole game seems like it's just way too early in development for any kind of early access release.  I have hope that the developers can improve upon the games issues, but until then, I will advise people to not make this purchase.

								I had a few issues with this game when I first started, this is why I gave it the thumbs down (for now)!You can eventually work your way through the tute (not easy as they don't explain things very well), but after that it says to go out side and take the vehicle for a ride. Problem is, you have to actually go up to a console inside the garage, (no idea why the vehicles are not inside the garage) and tell it you want to go outside, once outside, there is no vehicle, you have to press i to get a list of vehicles, then press i again to stop displaying the list of available vehicles, then point up in the air and press left mouse button to throw the vehicle in the air (again, no idea why you would do this), and then chase the vehicle as it will most likely start rolling away, no hand brake. Once you finally get a vehicle (remember to press x to start the motor), it is very hard to control it, there does not appear to be a button to press for brake, also it says to press page up and page down to zoom in and out, nothing happens. Not being able to zoom out a little makes it hard to see where your going. Editing vehicles is a little daunting at first, being unsure which parts fit with what, the tute vehicle requires a motor (when putting this in, it would be handy if the default angle of the motor would be suitable to put it in with out having to rotate it first), which I gave it, but when I went out side, it did not have a motor or even a left front wheel. Going to quick edit, it had a motor so you can not give it another, it also had all of the wheels, then switching to tune it had no motor or wheel (wtf). They could make this game a little more user friendly. Maybe add to the tute a highlighting function that lets you know where to place the parts that it is telling you to install!Controlling the ground vehicles is very hard, because the camera is doining its own thing, so not controllable by the user. Most of the time is will go behind the vehicle, so long as you are going in a straight line, so it is not too bad. What is bad, is that the angle of the camera is not high enough off the ground behind the vehicle, so you will have trouble seeing where you are going when going over hills. It would be much better to provide an option for the user to have some controll over the camera.Controlling the vehicle is also rather hard, especially at speed, it has major oversteer problems at speed, as well as the camera problem already mentioned, of not seeing where your going when going over hills.There does not seem to be much to do while driving, collecting objects and going over ramps. I have not progressed to air travel at this time, so don't know what there is to do up in the sky.At present they need to make it more user friendly, they are actively working on it and answering comments left here so I remain hopeful that this will end up being a really good game!!!

Nov 2016)I belive there was a fair deal of work in 2015, but it didn't peak my interest last year.This year, however there has been some changes.Phyzikov reached out to me and asked for some honest feedback on their current system to identify areas where they need to stabilize the system.First off the improvements I noticed:* An interactive tutorial to get you started with the game and understanding how to drive, sail and fly, as well as using your gadgets.* A lot of new islands that you can travel between, making the game feel less isolated.* Physics seems more stabilised.* Embedded video tutorial for building vehicles* A more lightweight interface for assembling vehicles, reducing the difficulty.* Scattered vehicles though the games are clearly marked with the glowing object and it provides a reason for the player to explore the islands.*MultiplayerIssues that needs improving:* Building isn't intuitive before the video is seen, an interactive tutorial would be good.* High speed can result in skipped collisions or rotations that goes on forever.* Surfaces that are not straight can result in wheel boots not being correctly applied.* If you swim in the deep ocean, you might risk being randomly teleport inside the center of an island under the waterlevel - in other words inside a mountain. (teleport gadgets resolves the issue)* No consequences of your actions - this can be considered good and fun, but it lacks immersion.So how would I rate this so far?The good part is that the developers are still working on the game and they seem to be doing some things actively, however sadly they have been working on this for 2 years now and is also being surpassed by other games who perhaps allow a certain amout of "arcadic physics".As a developer myself, I know it is really hard to model physics properly, so the challenge they are up against is a big one.My two cents would be to simplifly the physics with the aim to stabilize for playability and then add some gaming elements, so players can try completing challenges and build vehicles that are good at performing those challenges.I think it would be great to see with the multiplayer - not only because you can create content, but because you then can compete with that content - this could also be of interest for streamers.With that said, the current development seems to have focused on some different milestones than I had hoped for, and even though there are islands around me, which I think is nice, I would have prefered fewer islands and more ingame activities than building and exploring.Even though I might convince a friend to play pretend races with me and do some streaming with him, I doubt I could do it with the price tag of 17.99€, because the game itself simply lack activities or game mecanishms that challenges you to improve your vehicles.Make the most eco friendly vehicle and complete the lap.Make a solar powered plane, that is efficient enough to complete the lap without crashing.Complete a set of checkpoints (that requires a certain movability) and be the first to complete the lap.Do stunt jumps with various goals.And for the vehicle you can find when you explore the islands, it would be wonderfull if they got saved to your build projects, as a collection, making exploration even more meaningfull.I do hope the developers will look at the activites after working on stability, as it is my current main concern with the game. The improved physics over the past 2 years can clearly be felt and it is much more fun roaming around on the islands and flying planes now.I clear this review for a tiny positive recommendation, as i belive the developers are willing to put more value into the game for the customers and because a lot of the gamebreaking issues has been resolved. If you like making the most crazy vehicles and roam around in them, then go for it, and why not try the multiplayer with a friend while you are at it?While i'm a little skeptical about the pricetag, consider that buying the game from steam with its retail price, as it supports the development much better than going for a cheap key somewhere else.I leave my old review below for the sake of continuity, and because Igniuss's reply is related to that review.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------(4 of 13 found the old review helpfull)EARLY ACCESS REVIEW ( 19 Dec. 2014)tldr: Wait for a better version before investing.I agree with this guy: http://steamcommunity.com/app/325420/discussions/0/626329820885200239/There have been some updates, which i haven't experienced from play, but just based on writing they seem to be really good.It also seem to be quite the alpha version, with a fair deal of ability to change the game design, but also a fair deal of doubt in how it will turn out to be.My experience however is that most games tend to be feature complete while in EA. It doesn't seem to be the case here, so there might be changes to all the downsides i consider for this game.1. Physics:While this game tries to cover water, land and air at the same time, i don't expect a overhelming great physics in each part, as in a simulator. However there are some parts to the physic that i consider too flawish for a game like this. Mainly how breaking and a reverse vector applied to the resulting vector seems lacking.Also using a handbrake on a slope, should not give you more speed....When it comes to flying, it is quite clear that you need to consider how you balance the weight is important. That is a plus, but unfortunately some of the engines seems to be a bit extreme and will put you in a loop regardless of your controls.2. Game loop is too simple.  (build -> test)*While The game is indeed all about building and testing, it just seems like the testing aspect could use some sub-loops to create some kind of challenge or a feeling of achivement.While removing the orbs, from what i read and would determine myself, was a really good idea. Perhaps there could be some challenges which could unlock some non essential, or bonus like content.This is one of the things i hope will be improved in the future.These issues are the ones feel is most worth mentioning, as they make the game feel incomplete or borken.The constructing part is really good and interesting, so if those issues aren't important to you, then it is worth giving it a go, especially if you can get the game at discount.There are a chance that these will be improved, but it depends on how far the development is at the current stage. Hence I suggest people to wait a bit and see if these parts get any changes to the better.
